awd_titl_txt: Dimensions: Collaborative Research: Time after Time: Adaptive Seasonal Timing Drives the Sequential Origin of Community Biodiversity
awd_abstract_narration:
The timing of seasonal life cycles is a critical question underlying many biological processes, including the generation and maintenance of biodiversity and agriculture production and food security.  Animals and plants must synchronize their lives with the seasons to avoid freezing or overheating and to exploit seasonal resources. The goal of this grant is to understand how historic and contemporary shifts in seasonality can facilitate biological diversification in insect communities. In the short term, such shifts have caused rapid evolution of new crop pests and associated parasite communities. The proposed research tests 1) whether the same processes explain more ancient diversification of communities, and 2) whether changing climates will disrupt or promote diversification in the future. The results may inform many scientific fields, from basic research on the genesis of new species to applied control of agricultural pests. This project includes workshops with high school teachers and students to build curricula supporting "learning by doing" and meeting national standards, as well as providing training for graduate students and postdocs. 

This project includes genomic analysis of dipteran pest insects, including the apple fly Rhagoletis pomonella and blueberry maggot fly Rhagoletis mendax plus the community of parasitoid wasps that attack these flies. Genomic work will integrate with 1) functional studies of the overwintering hibernation of both the flies and the wasps from hormonal and molecular perspectives, and 2) computational simulations of the responses of the flies and their parasites to projected seasonal shifts resulting from climate change.

por.por_cntn:
This project was a collaboration between three labs at the University of Florida, Notre Dame, and the University of Colorado, Denver. This document primarily summarizes the work performed at the University of Colorado, Denver, most of which was performed in collaboration with one or both of the other institutions.

Our overarching goal was to better understand how an important agricultural pest insect, the apple maggot fly, has evolved its seasonality to better exploit its host plants, including cultivated apples. We also investigated how changes in seasonality may have cascading effects across insect communities, examining species of parasitoid wasps that attack the fly. We used complimentary approaches across biological disciplines to conduct these studies including genetic and genomic analysis of the genetic variation underlying rapid evolutionary responses, physiological studies of regulatory mechanisms that govern seasonality, and ecological studies examining how seasonality varies among populations of the fly that infest different host trees and are found at different geographic locations.

Intellectual Merit: We discovered that many different genes influence variation in seasonal timing of the fly in nature, which is critical to synchronize with the availability of the fruits that the fly infests. We further discovered that many of those genes affect rates of development of the fly, which in turn determine the timing of an overwintering, hibernating life cycle stage. Variation in these genes have rapidly evolved to allow the flies to attack the fruits of different plant species. We likewise have found evidence that many genes influence seasonality in parasitoid wasps that must track the fly seasonality, and continuing work in this area will reveal whether the parasitoids may be harnessing similar mechanisms. Complimentary, physiological studies revealed a new, proposed mechanism by which insects regulate the timing of overwintering by coopting similar developmental machinery that all insects use to regulate normal development when temperatures are warm.

Broader Impacts: Broader impacts of this project include the training of three postdoctoral scholars, eight graduate students, and seven undergraduate students at the University of Colorado, Denver. The University of Florida spearheaded activities to train high school teachers in science education as part of this project – those efforts are documented in the outcomes report for the collaborative portion of the project run at the University of Florida. Working with our partners at the University of Florida also helped us to develop concepts in science education that we used to help us propose a new Course Based Research Experience for Undergraduates (CURE) that has since been successfully funded and implemented at the University of Colorado, Denver.
